summary: This is an email chain from March 14, 2020, involving the Chief Public Information Officer of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY. The emails discuss a misleading Telegraph article about Prince Andrew's cooperation with the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The officer expresses frustration at being misquoted and clarifies that Andrew's lawyers had definitively refused an interview request, contrary to the article's implication of ongoing negotiations.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: The Duke of York is the subject of a Telegraph article and a U.S. investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. His lawyers reportedly refused an interview request from the SDNY.

persons.name: Chief Public Information Officer
persons.role: Chief Public Information Officer, U.S. Attorney's Office SDNY
persons.context: The author of the main email, expressing frustration at being misquoted by a Telegraph reporter regarding communications with Prince Andrew's lawyers.

connections.description: The Chief Public Information Officer's office contacted Prince Andrew's lawyers regarding an interview request for the Epstein investigation, which was refused.

events.title: Publication of Telegraph article on Prince Andrew
events.description: The Telegraph published an article claiming Prince Andrew was 'cooperating' with Jeffrey Epstein investigators, which the SDNY public information officer claims misrepresented their communications.

events.title: SDNY email discussion about Telegraph article
events.description: SDNY officials discuss the misleading Telegraph article via email. The Chief Public Information Officer states Prince Andrew's lawyers had already refused an interview request, contradicting the article's narrative.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY had contacted Prince Andrew's lawyers regarding an interview in the Epstein investigation.
Prince Andrew's lawyers definitively refused the interview request from the SDNY, stating 'there would be no interview'.
A Telegraph article from March 13, 2020, was characterized by an SDNY official as 'flagrantly misleading' for implying ongoing communication or negotiation with Andrew's team.
The SDNY Chief Public Information Officer expressed significant frustration at being misquoted by a British tabloid reporter.
